text: A rolling landscape. The rustling of leaves, and birdsong Thunder rumbles in the distance. There is no rain. A figure lies against a tree, eyes closed - this is SCHOFIELD, early-20s. Soft features. A man is sleeping next to him on the grass - BLAKE, 19, youthful, strapping.
Blake. Blake doesn’t stir.
Blake! Blake wakes. He’s in uniform, damp and crumpled - Lance Corporal chevrons adorn it.
(sleepily) Sorry, Sarge.
Pick a man, bring your kit.

Yes, Sarge. Blake stands, stiff limbs coming back to life. Schofield’s eyes are still shut. Blake holds out his hand Schofield. Schofield opens his eyes - they are gentle, wi Schofield grudgingly raises his hand for a lift. Blake heaves him to his feet - his uniform is identical t Blake's, same rank, the only difference is the brass woun stripe on Schofield’s left sleeve. They trudge towards Sanders, fastening their webbing. A smattering of SOLDIERS - same regiment - same state of fatigue and filth, lie around them. Stealing sleep.
Don’t dawdle.
No, Sarge. (CONTINUED )
After a few paces the long grass begins to give way to we trodden earth. Washing lines appears on either side of th Blake and Schofield move past them. After a while -
Did they feed us? Schofield shakes his head, he hands an envelope to Blake.
No, just mail. Blake’s eyes light up at the sight of the envelope, he te it open, reads it as he walks. Eyes scanning quickly, his face filling with warmth.
(reading) Myrtle’s having puppies. Blake finishes the note and slips it into a pocket.
You get anything?
No. Schofield doesn’t seem to mind. The mess tents are now alongside. Fires are stoked, cooki is underway. More soldiers mill about.

I'm bloody starving, aren’t you? I thought we might get some decent grub out here - only reason I decided against the priesthood. Schofield lets out a laugh. Blake looks on hungrily as th pass by the mess tents. Schofield rummages in his pockets, finds what he’s lookin for - a handkerchief with some food wrapped in it. Blake’ eyes fall on it hungrily.
What you got there?
Ham and bread. (CONTINUED )
Where did you find that?
I have my uses. Schofield breaks the bread in half. As he does this, they move down a slope, and begin to descend down into the ear into-- EXT. COMMS TRENCH —- DAY - CONTINUOUS A narrow Comms trench.
Here- The bread is stale, practically cardboard. Blake’s teeth struggle to get through it.
(mouth full of food) Tastes like old shoe.
Cheer up. This time next week it’1l be chicken dinner. The trench drops deeper into the earth...
Not me. Leave got cancelled.
They say why?
No idea. A beat. The world above has now disappeared.

It’s easier not to go back at all. Blake registers this - looks at him. The wider Rear Trench crosses their path. Chains of soldi move past them - shifting crates, ammunition, cooking, an medical supplies. (CONTINUED )
(looking at the soldiers) Something’s up. Expectation is growing in Blake. But Schofield looks concerned. They cut a route through the bustle.
Did you hear anything?
No.
Has to be the push, right? Men carrying things push past them. Blake watches.
Ten bob says we’re going up.
I’m not taking that bet.
Why? ‘Cos you know I’m right?
No. ‘Cos you haven’t got ten bob. Blake laughs. They follow Sanders into-
They turn into a wider second line trench.
In your own time, gentlemen... Up ahead, Sanders waits. Blake and Schofield put on speed, catch Sanders.
Is there news, Sarge?
News of what? (CONTINUED )
The big push. It was supposed to happen weeks ago. They told us we’d be home by Christmas.
(mild sarcasm) Yes, well, sorry to disrupt your crowded schedule, Blake, but the Brass Hats didn’t fancy it in the snow.
More’s the pity Sarge, I could have done with some turkey.

Well, I’1ll make sure to relay your displeasure to command. Ahead and above them is a web of telegraph wires - stretc overhead and along the trench. THREE ROYAL ENGINEERS are working on them, tagging and testing. They duck around th
So what’s on the cards then, Sergeant?
The Hun are up to something.
Any idea what?
No - but it’s bound to ruin our weekend. Sanders turns a corner, and comes to a stop. Just beyond is the dark, yawning mouth of a Dugout.
Now listen, Erinmore is inside, so tidy yourselves up. They are suddenly alert.
You never know - might be mentions in dispatches for this one, if you don't bugger it up. (CONTINUED )
Sanders gives them a look, and disappears inside the dugo Schofield quickly buttons up his tunic, hiding any sins t may be underneath. Blake nervously tidies himself, leans in to Schofield.
Must be something big if the General’s here. They enter.

Lit by paraffin lamps, it takes Schofield a moment for hi eyes to adjust to the half-light. He and Blake hand their rifles to the ORDERLIES, salute, and stand at attention. There is a simmering sense of unease in this place. In the centre of the room, there are two tables. On one t lie several maps, on the other are a number of large aeri reconnaissance photographs. GENERAL ERINMORE (50s), LIEUTENANT GORDON (40s) and a CAP are gathered around the far table, looking down at the aerials, talking in hushed tones. Other men watch from the shadows - TWO NCOs and ANOTHER ORDERLY.
Lance Corporals Blake and Schofield, Sir. General Erinmore turns around. Looks at Blake and Schofie
Which one of you is Blake?
Sir.
You have a brother, a Lieutenant in the 2nd Devons?
Yes, sir. Joseph Blake. Is he- (CONTINUED )
Alive, as far as I know. And with your help I’d like to keep it that way. Blake stares at Erinmore, he would do anything.
Sanders tells me you’re good with Maps. That true?
Good enough, Sir.
So. Erinmore turns the map to face Blake. The British lines a marked in blue, the German lines in red.
We are here. The 2nd Devons are advancing here. He points out a cross on the map at Croisilles Wood.
How long will it take you to get there? Blake hesitantly studies it. Croisilles Wood sits in the centre of a huge area of land, which is scored as occupie territory.
I don’t understand, Sir.
Sir, that land is held by the Germans.
Germans have gone. Shock plays on their faces.
Don’t get your hopes up. It appears to be a strategic withdrawal. They seem to have created a new line, nine miles back here, by the looks of it. (CONTINUED )

Erinmore runs his finger along the massed red lines of th German trenches and fortifications, newly drawn on the ma The new German Line - what came to be known as the Hinden Line - is huge, and cuts its way across the paper, almost intersecting with Croisilles Wood.

Colonel Mackenzie is in command of the 2nd. He sent word yesterday morning that he was going after the retreating Germans. He is convinced he has them on the run - that if he can break their lines now, he will turn the tide. He is wrong. Schofield watches Blake as he begins to register what thi might mean.
Colonel Mackenzie has not seen these aerials of the enemy’s new line. Erinmore turns to the other table.
Come round here, Gentlemen. Blake and Schofield move to the next table. They look dow the large aerial photographs.
Three miles deep. Field fortifications, defences and artillery the like of which we've never seen before. Beat.

The 2nd are due to attack the line shortly after dawn tomorrow. They have no idea what they are in for. And we can’t warn them - as a parting gift, the enemy cut all our telephone lines. Blake and Schofield are silent while they take this in. (CONTINUED )
Your orders are to get to the 2nd at Croisilles Wood, one mile south east of the town of Ecoust. Erinmore hands over an envelope to Blake. We see the distinctive red stamp of Army Command.

Deliver this to Colonel Mackenzie. It is a direct order to call off tomorrow morning’s attack. Erinmore speaks slowly, desperate to impress upon Blake a Schofield the gravity of this situation. Nothing can be misunderstood.

If you don’t, it will be a massacre. We would lose two battalions. Sixteen hundred men, your brother among them. Schofield hides his shock. But Blake looks at Erinmore, determination etched in his face: understood.
Do you think you can get there in time?
Yes, Sir.
Any questions?
No, Sir. Schofield eyes flick to Blake: No questions? Blake purpos doesn’t catch Schofield’s eye.
Good. Over to you, Lieutenant. The men salute Erinmore. Lieutenant Gordon, stands to one side.
Supplies, Gentlemen. (CONTINUED )
Lt. Gordon nods them over to a table. Various items are l out on it.

Map, torches, grenades, and a couple of little treats. They look. A folded map, two electric torches, two grenad and two small packs of Huntley and Palmer biscuits lie on table. They take them and start hastily putting them into their webbing. While they do:

Leave immediately, take this trench west, up on Sauchiehall Street, then north west on Paradise Alley at the front. Continue along the front line until you find the Yorks. Gordon slides a note into Blake’s top pocket.
Give this note to Major Stevenson. He’s holding the line at the shortest span of No Man’s Land. You'll cross there. Both men turn at the mention of No Man’s Land.
It will be daylight, Sir. They’1l see us.
No need to be concerned. You should meet no resistance. An Orderly hands them back their rifles. Blake moves towards the doorway. Schofield turns to Erinm
Sir, is it just us? Erinmore looks up.
“Down to Gehenna or up to the Throne (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
He travels the fastest who travels alone." Wouldn't you say, Lieutenant?
Yes, Sir. I would. The General looks at them levelly.
Good luck. Blake and Schofield turn and head through the door-
Schofield’s eyes wince in the daylight. A small curved br leads from the rear of the dugout back to the Second Line
Blake - let’s talk about this for a minute.
Why? Blake is already off, moving fast. Schofield moves after him, trying to fill and fasten his webbing as he goes.
Blake! Blake begins to move faster, setting a punishing pace. Bo clattering over the wooden boards.
We just need to think about it-
-There’s nothing to think about. It’s my big brother. Schofield runs to catch up, he falls in behind Blake, breathing heavy.
We should at least wait till it’s dark- (CONTINUED )
The Second cottages. collect th Schofield 12.
Erinmore said to leave immediately.
Erinmore’s never seen No Man's Land. We won’t make it ten yards. If we just wait-
You heard him. He said the Boche have gone.

Is that why he gave us grenades? line runs through a small row of derelict railway Braziers have been lit, men mill around queueing to eir rations. and Blake push themselves to the edge of the trench to get around the crush. Blake is through and clear, but Schofield bumps into a Sergeant. Blake keep;
Watch where you’re going!
Sorry. s pace, Schofield jogs to catch him.
All I’m saying is that we wait.
Yes, you would say that, because it’s not your brother, is it? Schofield moves alongside Blake again, grabs his arm.

Look, the last time I was told the Germans were gone, it didn’t end well. Blake shakes him off, and pushes his way forward, squeezi in and out of the lines of traffic - His shoulder and pack battering against MEN as he passes them. (CONTINUED )
You don’t know, Blake, you weren’t there. Ahead a group of men are bunched up collecting mail and parcels from the post bag. Gumming up the trench.

Excuse me... Excuse me! Blake and Schofield squeeze past them. Another junction. A painted sign: “SAUCHIEHALL STREET” po to a smaller branching comms line. Blake turns up it. Schofield follows- EXT. SAUCHIEHALL LINE (COMMS “DOWN” TRENCH)- CONTINUOUS Much narrower. Blake pushes onwards, going against the direction of the traffic. Schofield follows after him, si file, increasingly frustrated. Soldiers buffet against th A Sergeant snarls at them.
You're going up a down trench you bloody idiots.
Orders of the General, Sir. Schofield follows, catching the ire from the men Blake ha just passed. He checks his watch.
Alright, say the Boche have gone. Nine miles will take us, what, six hours? Eight at the very most. So we've got time to wait until the sun sets. Otherwise we'll be wide open-
-It’s enemy territory, we’ve got no idea what we’re walking into-
-Blake, if we're not clever about this, no one will get to your brother. (CONTINUED )
I will. Blake’s tone indicates that this is the end of the conversation. They are approaching a junction. They slow down. A flicke fear on both of their faces.

We're here. This is the front line. EXT. PARADISE (FRONT LINE) TRENCH —- CONTINUOUS The Front Line. A sign hangs on the junction wall: PARADISE ALLEY. Just visible above the trench wall to the front is an endless of wire.

Now we need to find the Yorks. There is an eeriness here, a sudden smothering silence. Blake looks around. Trying to work out which way is North West. Blake heads in that direction, moving fast again. Schofie follows alongside him. The trench stretches away from them, in a long line. Duckboards slick with mud mark out a path. There are many men here, and many pairs of eyes watch fro the shadows of dugouts. Crudely painted signs are strung up along the walls, dire warnings. We catch glimpses as Blake and Schofield pass:

head_text.subj: KEEP YOUR HEAD DOWN IN DAYLIGHT

text: They walk single file down the Front Line. TWO STRETCHER BEARERS are heading towards them, A MAN car between them. Schofield drops back, looks down. The man i unconscious, his face bandaged - two red bloodstains in p of eyes. Fear is rooting itself in Schofield. He fights it. (CONTINUED )
Schofield looks up, he’s briefly lost sight of Blake roun the next bend. He moves to catch up. He hears voices.
Here, watch who you’re shoving.

Get out of the way then. Schofield’s puts on speed, quickly pushes aside the soldi in front of him. He makes his way to Blake, three SOLDIERS have surrounded him. One, PRIVATE STOKES - a large red-haired bruiser, wi tattoos on his forearms - is gripping Blake’s tunic. Blak has him by the collar. Both are angry. Blake is on the ve of tears.
Let go.
Fuck you think you are, pushing wounded men around? Schofield is quickly into the fray, putting himself in between Blake and the Private.
Let go of me!
Stop.
Arsehole knocked our Sergeant down, the man’s fucking wounded- Beside them an NCO with a sling on, is being helped out o the mud.

Alright. I’m sorry, alright, I’m sorry. Blake struggles to get free, tears of frustration well in eyes. Schofield sees this, realises Blake is on the verge losing control. The Private’s hand balls into a fist, his anger simmering Schofield gets between them. (CONTINUED )
We’re on commission. Orders from the General.
Let me through. Stokes stops.
(levelly) Get out of the way.

Right. Just watch where you’re going. The other men move aside to give them a passage through. They keep moving. Schofield is a step behind Blake, he st glances at him, concerned. The two men walk on, the silence heavier. After a while -
It’s bloody quiet... A beat. Blake looks at Schofield.
Was it like this before Thiepval? The name does something to Schofield. Fear clings to him. pushes it away.
I don’t remember.
You don’t remember the Somme?
Not really.
Well, you did alright out of it. At least wear your ribbon. Beat.
Don’t have it anymore. (CONTINUED )
They push on round the next bend.

What? You lost your medal? Before he can answer, the trench suddenly expands - the b wall has been blown out into a large crater. Debris and sandbags are strewn around. A small team of DIGGERS work it with picks and shovels, breaking up the earth, pulling body parts from the mud, putting them in empty sandbags.
Stay low. Schofield climbs over the rubble and sandbags, crushing h body to keep his head below the front parapet. Blake follows. One of the diggers turns to Schofield, his voice a harsh whisper.
God's sake. Careful there, you’re stepping on the dead. Schofield looks at the sandbag, 15 inches by 25. Red is rusting through it.
That’s our Sergeant - Schofield quickly moves off the bag.
Be better washing them out of this dugout with a bloody hose.
Do you know where the Yorks are?

The next bend you’1l be standing on top of half of them. Shot to hell two nights ago. Blake and Schofield continue. They slip round a bend and a small bay. They stop by two men - one is burning the lice from his clothes with a lighter Another, BUCHANAN, sits against th back wall, a small dog on his lap. (CONTINUED )
Yorks? Buchanan nods.
Yes, Corp.
Where’s Major Stevenson?
Killed a couple of nights ago, Corporal. Lieutenant Leslie has command.
Where can we find him? Buchanan nods down the line.

Next dug-out. They round the bend and spot the dugout. It has been badl shelled, but patched and re-built. A fire is lit in a bra just outside the door. Inside, a provisions bag and a few other wooden items hang from a rafter, out of reach of th rats.
Here. LT. LESLIE is asleep on a small camp bed, his arm over hi eyes. A couple of ORDERLIES sit or lie nearby. They approach the sleeping Leslie.
Sir? He doesn’t stir. Blake speaks louder.
Lieutenant Leslie, Sir? Leslie stirs a little, he doesn’t move his arm from his e
What is it? (CONTINUED )
We have a message from General Erinmore. Leslie looks up, his face shines with sweat, his voice is croaky, full of flu, a little delirious.
Are you our relief? Schofield shakes his head.
No, Sir.
Then when the fucking hell are they due?
We don’t know, Sir. But we’ve got orders to cross here. Blake offers the letter. Leslie sits up. Looks at them queerly.
That is the German front line.
We know, Sir. If you'll just take the letter- Blake hands over Erinmore’s letter. Leslie sighs, tears i open and reads quickly.
(as he reads) Settle a bet, what day is it?
Friday.
Friday. Well, well, well. None of us was right. This idiot thought it was Tuesday. (off the letter) Are they out of their fucking minds? (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
One slow night, and the brass think the Hun have just gone home.
(looking at Blake) Do you think they’re wrong, Sir?
We lost an officer and three men two nights ago. They were shot to bits patching up wire. We dragged two of them back here. Needn’t have bothered. Blake is determined to press on.
Sir, the General is sure the enemy have withdrawn. There are aerials of the new line- Leslie gets to his feet.
Shut up. We’ve fought and died over every inch of this fucking place, now they suddenly give us miles? Schofield turns and stares at Blake. Blake won’t meet his eye.
It’s a trap. Leslie leans in to Schofield.
But, chin up. There’s a medal in it for sure. Nothing like a scrap of ribbon to cheer up a widow. Schofield stares at him like he would lift him out of his boots with one punch.
Alright. Leslie walks out of the dugout. As he walks- (CONTINUED )
Where’s the nearest way through, Sir?
Our wire’s a mess. But there is a path through. Of sorts. He leads them a few paces to a small dead-end lookout tre half earth, half corrugated steel. At the end of it isa rudimentary periscope.
(to the soldier) Rushworth! Let him look. The soldier manning it steps away to allow them to look. Blake presses his eye to the lens.
Straight ahead, to the left, past the dead horses- Blake squints, moves the periscope. While Blake does this Leslie lights a cigarette, his hands shaking.

There’s a gap directly behind them. Useful, because if it’s dark you follow the stench. When you get to the second wire, look out for the bowing chap. There’s small break just beside him. As Blake scans the terrain with the periscope, Schofield methodically prepares himself.
The German line is a hundred and fifty odd yards after that. Watch out for the craters. They’re deeper than they look. You fall in, there’s no getting out. Leslie indicates for them to follow.
This way. Leslie kicks at a sleeping PRIVATE KILGOUR as he walks. (CONTINUED )
Wake up, Kilgour. (to himself) Bloody waste of space.
Any cover, Sir? Anywhere to jump off from? Leslie leads them to a wide ladder leaning against the tr wall.

No. The sap trench was blown to hell weeks ago. It’s full of bodies anyway. Your best bet is to pop over here. Blake and Schofield stop by the ladder, ready themselves, checking and loading their rifles, fixing their bayonets
If you do get shot, try to make it back to the wire. We won’t come after you, not until it’s dark. And, if by some fucking miracle you do make it, send up a flare.
Don’t have any, Sir. Leslie gestures impatiently to a nearby PRIVATE KILGOUR.
Well get him one, Kilgour! Make yourself useful.
Yes, Sir. Kilgour goes to fetch the flare gun, Leslie amuses himsel

(sprinkling whisky on the men) “Through this holy unction may the Lord pardon thee whatever sins or faults thou hast committed” Leslie laughs mirthlessly. Schofield and Blake try to sta focused. Kilgour hands Leslie a flare pistol and two cartridges. (CONTINUED )
I do hate losing these to the Hun. So when they start shooting at you, could you be so kind as to throw it back, there’s a good chap. Blake tucks the flare and cartridges into his pack.

Cheerio. Leslie steps back. A crowd of MEN have now gathered behin him to watch Blake and Schofield, their faces a combinati of shock and fascination. Blake and Schofield climb onto the firing step. Schofield looks at Blake, speaks quietly to him.
You sure? Blake isn’t. But he nods.
Yes. Blake goes to climb over. Schofield stops him.

Age before beauty. Schofield takes a deep breath, and goes first. He puts on hand over the parapet. Then the other. Slowly he advances up, his head inching over the protecti of the trench. His hand is shaking, he drives it into the mud, grasping for purchase. Everyone is still, breathless, listening for the enemy to fire. Schofield drags his body up and over into -
Vast, almost unbearably open after the close quarters of trench. A light mist hangs low over the land. (CONTINUED )

The ground is treacle-like. Schofield’s hands and knees s into it as he pulls himself forward, his eyes are trained through the British wire towards the German lines. The whole world is lunar and empty. Earth pounded to atom all mounds and holes. Nothing moves. Nothing lives. The only sound is Blake’s breathing as he heaves himself of the trench beside Schofield. Both men are still for a beat. Hunched down low on their knees, two nocturnal animals caught in the daylight. British wire runs in loops ahead of them, tangled and haphazardly strung. A mess to navigate through. They get to their feet and move forwards over the slick earth, towards the putrid remains of the horses. Breathin through their mouths, trying to deal with the stench. A layer of black fur covers the animals, as Schofield and Blake close in on them they see the fur is actually flies hundreds of them. Schofield moves past the remains and through the first br in the wire. The path is pocked with craters and puddles, shrapnel litters everything. Blake follows Schofield through the channel - ahead, on t second wire, is “the bowing chap” - a GERMAN SOLDIER, dea bent double over the wire, one arm outstretched in a cour manner, as if bowing. Schofield doesn’t linger on the dead German, doesn’t look his face. He focuses on the task at hand. To the side of man is a small gap in the razor wire, easy to miss withou the landmark. Schofield struggles to further pull apart t dense tangle of wire. He indicates for Blake to pass thro As he does so, Schofield slips in the mud. His hand instinctively closes around the wire. It slices into his palm, hooking into his flesh. Bright red seeps along his hand, he wrenches it back, tea the skin to free himself. A heavy breath hisses out of hi He balls his hand into a fist to stem the bleeding.
You alright? (CONTINUED )
Blake looks at him with concern. Schofield nods that he’s fine.

Look for cover. Everything after here is unnatural land. Craters are goug out of the earth. There is a rise and fall to this stretc but no flow or reason to it. About a hundred yards from them, in the distance, is an artificial horizon, something grey, mesh-like, stretching entire length of the land - The German Wire. Occasional d trees dot the land beyond. Blake goes into the closest crater. He looks to Schofield some silent communication. Schofield’s eyes pull out a pa where there isn’t one.

Sap trench. Schofield goes first, crouching low, moving faster now, picking his way towards a hole in the earth. And then jumps directly into the old sap trench. Blown out and neglected, it is now little more than a dit but it offers a stretch of cover. Schofield checks his wounded hand. It pulses blood. He fe as if he is being watched. He looks around. Next to him is the body of a German soldier; face down in mud, rats are on the corpse, feasting. Blake jumps into the sap just next to Schofield. He lands right next to A DEAD MAN, looking straight at them. He is sitting up, his lips and eyes have been chewed off by rat White teeth grin in a pale face. Blake reflexively scrambles back in horror, knocking into Schofield. Schofield slips, reaches out to steady himself and grabs at the first thing he finds - the BODY OF THE GERMAN. Schofield’s wounded hand lands on the man’s back and sink right through. Schofield’s cut hand goes into the putrid flesh. Beside him, Blake is frozen. Panicking. (CONTINUED )

Schofield gestures to him - ‘stay calm’. Blake tries to steady himself. They move further along the side of the sap trench. Schof peers out. About eighty yards now to the German wire. They gather themselves. Schofield takes the lead. He pull himself out of the sap, Blake follows. They move, crouched low. Watching. Waiting for guns to op on them. Silence. The land is flatter here. There is an eerie feeling of emptiness and silence. Schofield and Blake keep moving forwards, trying to stay focused. Crouching to keep low. The mud is like oil, but some things are solid underfoot. Outlines of guns, shrapnel, unexploded shells, bodies. Suddenly a loud sound approaching. TWO PLANES. Blake and Schofield both move quickly to the nearest shel hole. They throw themselves in and freeze. Keeping the br of their helmets low, hiding their faces from the planes above. Blending in to the landscape around them.
(Sotto) Stay still. The engines grow louder. The planes fly close overhead, a then begin to recede into the distance. Both men now turn their heads to look at them.
(Sotto) They’re ours. Blake nods.
(Sotto) Keep going. We’re half way. They move back out into the open expanse. (CONTINUED )

Large shell holes appear on either side of them. They pic their way through them, balancing carefully along the rid They climb to the top of a small hillock and suddenly on other-side - vertigo. The ground falls away steeply in a crater, stories deep. They look down into it.

There’s a gap in the wire. We can see the base of the crater: The nearest line of Ge wire has been split by the blast, and hangs limply down t side wall of the crater, the other half of it disappears a huge pool of water at its base. They meet each other’s gaze. An obvious way through the w It’s clear they need to go down into the crater. They slide carefully down the steep bank. At the base of the crater the water is fathomless - the colour of mucus, and the same consistency. A DEAD GERMAN floats in it, bloated. Blake follows in Schofield’s exact footsteps, walking aro the edge of the pool. Blake looks into the pool. Things float in it. Bodies. Th pages of a letter, a cigarette tin, a water canteen. Ahead of them, halfway up the far bank another line of Ge wire - the main one - is suspended across the crater. The is a gap beneath the wire. They climb up the far bank towards the gap. Blake is struggling.

Sco... Schofield helps him up the slope. The main German wire is a huge thicket of razor wire, den than a hedgerow. Using their hands, they dig into the mud sides of the crater, and pull themselves upwards, through German wire. Schofield looks - close to him, caught on the wire, a sma clump of human hair blows in the breeze. (CONTINUED )
Hands and bayonets digging deep into the muddy bank, they haul themselves out of the crater. Ahead of them is the German Front Line.

There! That’s the front line. They lift their rifles and aim them towards the German li Blake moves first. He quickly approaches the German trenc Schofield is next to him. Both men suck in a breath and stand tall, leaning over th German sandbags. Their rifles sweep in unison down the length of the trenc Empty. Schofield turns to Blake.

Fuck me. They really have gone. They look around in awe - this trench is massive, fortified... and seemingly abandoned. Intermittent shell holes have levelled large sections. Blake and Schofield drop down into the trench.

This trench is better crafted than the British trench. De and well reinforced, and eerily empty. They are alone. To one side the trench is smashed in. A mountain of earth debris. Blocked. Schofield crouches, attends to his bleeding hand. Blood o out of it.
Your hand alright?
Put it through an effing German. Schofield has taken out his canteen, he pours water on hi sliced up palm. Blake keeps watch.
Patch it up. You’ll be wanking again in no time. (CONTINUED )

Wrong hand. Blake laughs. Blake moves off, rifle ready. Schofield follows, wrapping bandage round his hand as they move. He tightens the dres with his teeth. Red seeps through the white gauze. Ahead of them is a brazier, full of spent white coal dust Blake kicks it over, the white dust crumbles, red embers - wisps of smoke. Still smouldering. Schofield turns to Blake, his eyes are on the embers too.
They’re not long gone. Blake hands tighten on his rifle, he pushes off, heading down-
Blake leads them into the deep, narrow trench. Creeping forward quickly, eyes darting ahead, looking for any enem The comms trench opens out into-
Blake hovers by the mouth of the comms trench, peeking ou Another dead end.

Ahead, on the plain, an oak tree towers. Untouched. On high branches, leaves dance in the wind. Schofield walks towards it. He sits on the far side of his back to the trunk. The land stretches out ahead of the early light. He listens to the wind in the leaves. Birdsong. 117. to it. the it, him in He undoes his breast pocket. He pulls out the small tobac tin. He stares at it. He takes a deep breath and opens it. Two photographs. Schofield lifts them out, looks at them: TWO YOUNG GIRLS, his daughters. They smile at the camera. He looks at the other - his WIFE. He turns the photo over. On the back, her handwriting: “Come back to us.” He stares at it for a long beat. The pain on his face ebbs into longing. Love. He closes his eyes and feels the sun on his face. THE END.
